conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration graph provided.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 5 seconds, the acceleration remains constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, the acceleration is zero.
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, the acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, the acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 0 to t = 1 second with average acceleration 1 m/s², resulting in Δv_1 = 1 m/s.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 1 to t = 5 seconds with constant acceleration 2 m/s², resulting in Δv_2 = 8 m/s.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 5 to t = 55 seconds with zero acceleration, resulting in Δv_3 = 0 m/s.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 55 to t = 56 seconds with average acceleration -1 m/s², resulting in Δv_4 = -1 m/s.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 56 to t = 59 seconds with constant acceleration -2 m/s², resulting in Δv_5 = -6 m/s.
Calculate the velocity change from t = 59 to t = 60 seconds with average acceleration -1 m/s², resulting in Δv_6 = -1 m/s.
Sum the changes in velocity to find the total velocity at t = 60 seconds: v_60 = 1 + 8 + 0 - 1 - 6 - 1 = 1 m/s.
The speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds is 1 m/s.
